class_notes:
For History Honors students only


(Permission Required Prior to Enrollment)


The course guides students accepted into the History honors program towards a research proposal for their honors thesis. The class consists of discussion of historiographical and methodological issues as well as practical guidance in the application of research techniques and the design of a thesis. There will be common readings pertaining to the academic discipline of History as well as individual readings pertaining to each student's thesis project (four book reviews). The main focus lies on the gathering of research materials (annotated bibliography, book reviews, primary sources), the writing of a thesis proposal (multiple drafts) and a public presentation of the honors projects.


Book to purchase: Lynn Hunt, History. Why it Matters (2018). $11.
Common readings will be available on Course Reserve. Individual readings will be determined at the beginning of the semester.
course_description: For honors students in history. Addresses historiographical and methodological issues, and offers practical guidance in thesis design and research, with details and emphases at discretion of instructor.
